item.title: Stability AI Announcement — Stability AI
item.description: Earlier today, Emad Mostaque resigned from his role as CEO of Stability AI and from his position on the Board of Directors of the company to pursue decentralized AI. The Board of Directors has appointed Shan Shan Wong, our Chief Operating Officer, and Christian Laforte, our Chief Technology Officer
item.author:
(23 Mar
Written By Bryce Wilson)

item.description: This post covers what I've learned about Akamai's VPC, how I deployed one with Terraform, and why it's good for security.

item.title: Users, Tools, Platforms, and the Shifting Goals of Software
item.description: I've been around long enough now to remember when we used different words to refer to our favorite apps and websites. Long before the words Platform, Service, or Ecosystem infected our discourse there were Tools. And I think we need fewer of the former and more of the latter.
item.author: (by Brian Schrader)

item.title: static vs dynamic types
item.description: The debate between statically and dynamically typed languages has always been a hot topic in software development. Designing types for a problem can feel like solving a puzzle—fun for some and frustrating for others. But the real question is: Do you know how to represent the domain? While the alpha engineer may claim they do, understanding a domain comes from observing patterns over time. The challenge in business, where code is most commonly used, is collecting and understanding the data needed to define these types accurately.
item.author: (breadchris)

item.title: AI and the Complexity of Code | Koen van Gilst
item.description: Large Language Models like ChatGPT and CoPilot have a dual role in simplifying and complicating software development. Using a simple experiment this post explores how LLMs often lead to an increase in code complexity.
item.author: (Koen van Gilst)

item.title: Brutally honest career advice to my younger self - Noah Kagan
item.description: I’m 42. The first 10 years of my career were a roller coaster of emotions: Rejected by MSFT Rejected by Google (2x) Fired by FB after 9 months Fired by mint .com after 10 months Built 20+ startups that didn’t work out But I’ve also: Built AppSumo to $100M/year in revenue Grew my YouTube channel […]
item.author: (Jay Yang)

item.title: Daily Driving Ubuntu Asahi for Over a Month
item.description: I recently got laid off and got 100% custody of my MacBook Pro. I’m not a fan of macOS, but I run it because Apple’s systems are locked down. Not anymore. Asahi Linux has come a long way, spawning Fedora Asahi and, more recently, Ubuntu Asahi. Ubuntu has been my primary operating system for ~14 years, so the chance of running it natively on my MacBook Pro was appetizing. With full admin access to the laptop, I installed Ubuntu Asahi.

item.title: Clean Domain Driven Todo List in Go
item.description: Learning Golang, domain driven or clean architecture. This quick tutorial showcases how you can start building services by following a clean, domain driven solution. It uses Golang as the language of choice, but the ideas are transferrable to any coding language

item.title: Boss Chief Bets
item.description: Learn how to build a sports betting model for college basketball. Follow my journey and get insights into the process.

item.title: Cost-Benefit Analysis of Healthy Emotional Boundaries
item.description: Learn how to set healthy emotional boundaries to reduce stress, anxiety, and boost your mental well-being. Discover the surprising benefits of boundaries for stronger relationships & a happier you!

item.title: Poking at Threads in the Fediverse
item.description: Yesterday, the Threads team started rolling out their fediverse integration to users in the US, Canada, and Japan. I tried signing up for this when I saw that some users were boosting their first cross-network posts. Sadly, the sign-up process 1 didn’t work all Thursday for me. It all worked this morning though, and I’ve spent some time poking at it. The sign-up process is quite nice when it’s working. There’s a nice overview of federated networking as part of the sign-up/consent flow. ↩
item.author: (Gavin Anderegg)

item.title: Roll your own ZFS NAS
item.description: Recently I've noticed an uptick in the engagement found within the self-hosting community, so I've decided to start a series of posts that look into why and how I handle self-hosting. Today's post will focus on data storage and will look into some of the options available when it comes to data backups.

item.title: I Hate Sexy
item.description: Okay, I don’t actually hate sexy, I’m just not into “sexy” businesses. If I’m rolling into a pitch with a pair of shades saying, this is the “hottest new thing - like sex but with computers”, I’ve done something wrong. After working for and with many startups, the things I am most interested in are businesses that don’t ooze sex appeal. I like businesses that enable positive changes or facilitate important aspects of our life.

item.title: Fast SQL Bulk Inserts With C# and EF Core
item.description: Explore various methods for fast bulk inserts in SQL with C# and EF Core, highlighting techniques like Dapper, EF Core optimizations, EF Core Bulk Extensions, and SQL Bulk Copy.
